title: "The New Retro" large number 2
content:
Hello,  
Im hunting for this font or something close to it.  
It is the large number two shown here that Im keen in finding.

| Attachment | Size |
| --- | --- |
| [FAIRspot-James-White-signalnoise-Two-Smashing-Years.jpg](http://web.archive.org/web/20090406025820/http:/typophile.com/files/FAIRspot-James-White-signalnoise-Two-Smashing-Years.jpg) | 281.83 KB |

 [‹ What is the font of this please??](http://web.archive.org/web/20090406025820/http:/typophile.com/node/56618 "Go to previous forum topic") [Denver Post? ›](http://web.archive.org/web/20090406025820/http:/typophile.com/node/56368 "Go to next forum topic")
author: jennaarmstrong

comments.content: Some version of [Kabel](http://web.archive.org/web/20090406025820/http:/new.myfonts.com/fonts/adobe/itc-kabel/ultra/?testdrive=custom%3D0%26seed%3D29%26dock%3D0%26size%3D72%26w%3D720%26src%3Dcustom%26text%3D2%26fg%3D000000%26bg%3Dffffff%26goodies%3Dot.liga) should get you quite close.

A number of the multiline fonts like Aki Lines, Zeppelin, and some of the Prisma clan shown [here](http://web.archive.org/web/20090406025820/http:/www.bowfinprintworks.com/LinedFontGuide01.html) might be even closer. There was at least one digital version of Aki Lines, from Image Club.

- Mike Yanega

Sorry if it seems like I’m hijacking this thread, but I’ve been looking for similar 2’s. I love the way the counter looks a bit like a defiant fist. The sample on the left is the second-class marking on Polish railway carriages. On the right is a building number in London. I can see these are different faces from the different way the down stroke meets the bottom stroke, something which cannot be seen in Jenna’s sample. I’m imagining a lot of customising work has been done to that, if it isn’t in fact drawn from scratch. I’m hoping mine might be more recognisable.

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20090406025820im_/http:/typophile.com/files/2two_5462.jpg)

I think each of these samples is from a different font/typeface. The right hand 2, with the pointed ’nose’ looks a bit like Kabel, as Craig Eliason mentioned above, only not quite as closed. I think this is a feature of some Bauhaus-Art Deco styles.

- Mike Yanega
